Definition: In this task, you will be given an utterance and recent dialogue context containing past 3 utterances (if available). Your task is to output 'Yes' if the utterance contains the self-need strategy, and 'No' if it does not. The self-need strategy is a selfish negotiation strategy used to create a personal need for an item in the negotiation. For example, a participant might point out that they sweat a lot to show preference towards water packages.

Positive Examples.input:
Context: 'That sounds pretty reasonable as I am in need of firewood the most. Would it be most reasonable to each take what we need most and split the water down the middle?' 'Yes, it would.' 'I think that sounds fair. The problem is that there are 3 waters and one of us would get two and the other one. How should we sort that?'
Utterance: 'You can take the two water. I am not that thirsty most days.'
Positive Examples.explanation: In this utterance, the participant does not use self-need since they do not talk about any need for themselves.

Positive Examples.input:
Context: 'hello, how are you today?' 'Great.  Though I am a bit stressed.  I could use a camping trip. ' 'yes, me too. i am going to one. but i need some food.'
Utterance: 'Yeah.  I like to go for long hikes so for that I need water and food.  '
Positive Examples.explanation: This is correct since the participant mentions that they would need water for their long hikes.

Negative Examples.input:
Context: 'Hello. I am so looking forward to this camp out. My daughter just called and said she is going to come and bring some of her firiends. 🙂' 'Hello! That sounds pretty reasonable to me. I was going out with a bunch of my buddies. We like to hike a lot in the sun, so we need lots of water. How does it sound if i take all the food and water, but you get all the firewood?' 'I love hiking. My daughter is bringing extra water. So we could trade the water for the firewood. We do need just a little food as I didn't plan on having an extra person.'
Utterance: 'Hmm, okay, that sounds reasonable. How does 3 water, 2 food and 1 firewood for me, and all the rest for you sound?'
Negative Examples.explanation: There is no self-need discussed in the utterance. Hence, the correct answer here is 'No'.

Negative Examples.input:
Context: 'we want to explore the animals in the area birds and just enjoy all the nice views.' 'Cool, that sounds very nice and relaxing 🙂. It kinda sounds like my husband, he likes to do things like these with no concrete plan and just decides on the spot what he wants to do. The only problem with it is that he dumps all the planning on me so I have to make sure I have extra of ANY possible idea he has.' 'Yes we always get stuck making the plans so can I have 2 firewood and you get 2 food and 2 water? Please respond a little faster with your messages that would be very nice'
Utterance: 'Unfortunately, I need the firewood to make campfires. Since you are planning to cook a romantic camping meal, don't you need food?'
Negative Examples.explanation: This is wrong. The participant clearly discusses the need of firewood for making campfires. Hence, the correct answer is 'Yes'.

Instances.input:
Context: '🙂  You're being very accommodating! So right now I have 2 food, 2 water and 1 firewood. And you have 1 food, 1 water and 2 firewood, right?' 'that sounds good to me, if you want to give me another food i would take it but ok if not ' 'I wish we could split packages in two!  How about if I give you another food and I keep two firewood?'
Utterance: 'that is ok, the original you stated will work, 2 food, 2 water and 1 firewood for you, and 2 firewood, 1 food and 1 water for me , i need to lose weight anyways '

Context: 'No food, just 2 water, 3 firewood' '3 water, 3 firewood?' 'I could do 3 water, 1 firewood, if you would like more water'
Utterance: 'sure, if you throw in 1 food'

Context: 'I would love to have the Firewood the most. ' 'Unfortunately I need firewood the most too. How about I take 2 firewood, 2 food, and 1 water?' 'I feel that I am not getting a fair deal. '
Utterance: 'Then what do you think is fair?'

Context: 'Hi, I will need alot of water as I need it to stay alive.' 'I agree, with camping i feel there are many uncertainties. Finding clean water would be too difficult, best to take as much water as possible. '
Utterance: 'I will also need some Firewood too to start a fire'

Context: 'I was thinking about 2 units of firewood and 1 unit of food and one unit of water, what are you going to be needing this for?' 'I can do that. I am going camping in the fall with my family so we need a lot of food. We're camping by the lake so if you want I can give you an extra unit of water.' 'sure thats sounds fair, so that would leave you with two units of food one unit of firewood and one unit of water then?'
Utterance: 'That sounds fair to me. Have fun with the kiddo!'

Context: 'Hello, what are your preferences for extra supplies?  I am greatly in need of food and water.  We will be doing a lot of activity in a hot, dry climate.🙂'
Utterance: 'I prefer firewood because I will get cold at night. I forgot blankets ☹️'

Context: 'In that case I exchange all the water only for all your firewood' 'I can give you all the firewood - but as a diabetic, I still need at least one extra package of food for my blood sugar levels. So, as my final offer I can give you all of the firewood, and two extra packages of food. Do you agree to these terms?' 'No, I give out only one extra package of food'
Utterance: 'I think you misunderstood what I said. I said that *you* would receive all of the firewood, and two extra packages of food. '

Context: 'Are you most interested in the food? 😮' 'yeah I didn't pack enough for my trip, so I'm a little worried about my supplies.' 'I see. I wouldn't want you to go hungry. ☹️'
Utterance: 'thank you for that.'
